text: you've probably heard of the Iditarod
the famous dogsled race across Alaska
it's sometimes called the toughest race
on earth but there might be a race
that's a little tougher this is the
start of the 2008 Alaska ultra sport
Invitational race the racers braved the
same frozen terrain that the mushers do
you can freeze your toes and thumbs and
fingers to layer as hard as a ton to ice
but there's one big difference in this
race there are no dogs it's just human
power on foot skis or bicycles traveling
350 grueling miles of frozen Alaskan
wilderness
last year 41 racers started and 29
finished so why would anyone want to do
this sometimes I do think why did I sign
up for this what am i doing I don't know
if there is an answer actually because
you know all the time you're doing it
you just think you're totally mad it's
it's nearly a spiritual experience I
feel it's like a pilgrimage prospective
racers a New Yorker and an Englishman
have traveled thousands of miles to this

flats just south of Wasilla lay over the

instructors are built and Cady merchants
who also organized the race and have

I think riding 350 miles is okay it's

in 32 degree water you'd probably have

is a constant especially when the trail

and within a few minutes the trail will
be gone and then you're walking the only
